raw_text:
Apple Mac mini gets warm welcome
 
 The Mac mini has been welcomed by Apple fans, industry experts and PC users.
 
 The release of the tiny, low-cost machine is seen as a good move for Apple which currently has a small share of the desktop computer market. Mac watchers and some analysts say the Mac mini will go a long way to help Apple appeal to the mass of consumers. They speculate that the Mac mini will be bought by iPod owners and those wanting an easy-to-use and administer second home computer.
 
 "It's the bravest move they have made yet," said Jonny Evans, news editor at Macworld magazine. Mr Evans said the combination of low cost, small size and huge numbers of iPod users could make it a big success.
 
 He thought that the machine would appeal to those that like Apple technology but who before now have balked at paying high prices for its hardware. "It's deeply affordable," he said. "Plus you know that you do not get viruses or all of the associated problems." Already, he said, PC owning friends had declared that they would be buying one. Interest in the new products launched at Macworld expo was so strong that websites for Apple's store and the show struggled to cope with demand. According to response statistics gathered by Netcraft many visiting the Apple store in the wake of Mr Jobs' speech suffered lengthy response times. The Macworld Expo site was completely overwhelmed and went offline.
 
 "I think fundamentally it's a good idea because it's cheap even for a PC," said Nick Ross, deputy labs editor at PC Pro. Apple's work on making things easy to use would also help the Mac mini win fans, he said. "I think people expect it just to work now and really it should," hesaid. The Mac mini could find a role in homes that need a second computer that is easy to install and administer, he said. "For browsing the web, e-mail and all kinds of basic duties it's going to be absolutely adequate," said Mr Ross. Ian Fogg, broadband and personal technology analyst at Jupiter Research, agreed that the Mac mini could be very popular. "Apple has been hoping that sales of the iPod will have a halo effect on the sales of the Mac," he said.
 
 Before now, he said, Apple has been seen as a premium brand. But, he said, the Mac mini changed that perception. "It's a particularly good price when you see that it's Apple that is doing it," he said. Apple expects the Mac mini to sell for £339 in the UK and $499 in the US. Adding extras such as a larger hard drive, more memory and networking options will increase the basic price. It will go on sale from 22 January. "For consumers interested in style, design and small size - which is what the majority of iPod customers are interested in - it's a natural next step," said Mr Fogg. Apple has traditionally done well in the market that the Mac mini is aimed at, said Mr Fogg, who also expected many PC makers to release copycat devices in reaction.
 
 His only misgivings were over how easy other consumers, other than iPod owners, would find using the machine. He said anyone wanting to use the Mac mini with the peripherals from an old computer may find it odd to have something so small and sleek next to a hulking monitor. "They'd be much more likely to pair a Mac mini with a LCD or flat panel monitor which increases the upgrade cost," he said. Those with flat screens and LCD monitors are likely to have bought them recently and not be in the market for a new machine.
 
 There are also questions over whether the Mac mini will work with very old peripherals, such as display, keyboard and mouse. The Mac mini also fell short of being a media server that can be a video recorder as well as a store for all the digital music, movies and images people accumulate, said Mr Fogg. "The Mac mini is not quite ready for that yet," he said. "It does not have the right connectors that fit a TV screen or enough storage." Said Mr Fogg: "It's very much a computer." One dissenting opinion came from Brian Gammage, vice-president of research at analysts Gartner. He said: "I don't think it changes the world." Although the Mac mini was very cheap for an Apple computer, it was still expensive compared to many PCs. Also, he said, it appealed in categories that few consumers care about when buying a home computer. "The PC world is a pile-em-high, sell-em-cheap market," he said, "and all of them are pretty interchangeable." "Since the days when Apple ruled the personal computing world its market share has been on a long, slow decline," he said. "Every few years it does something to give its market share a kick then it starts to go back down again," said Mr Gammage. The release of the Mac mini fit perfectly with this trend, he said.
llama3.2:1b: The Apple Mac mini has been welcomed by fans and industry experts, who see it as a good move for the company to appeal to mass consumers.
It is expected to be bought by iPod owners and those wanting an easy-to-use computer.
The machine's low cost, small size, and high numbers of iPod users make it a potentially successful product.
Interest in new Apple products at Macworld was strong, with many visitors to the show declaring they would buy a Mac mini.
Apple expects the device to sell for £339-£499, with additional features increasing its price.
The machine's design and functionality may appeal to consumers who prefer Apple technology but have been deterred by high prices from other brands.
llama3.2:3b: Apple's new Mac mini has received positive reception from fans and experts, seen as a good move for the company to expand its desktop computer market share.
Industry analysts believe it will appeal to iPod owners and those seeking an easy-to-use second home computer.
The machine's low cost, small size, and ease of use are expected to be major selling points.
However, some question whether it can work with older peripherals and has limitations in terms of media capabilities.
Analyst Brian Gammage believes the Mac mini does not change the world but will help Apple gain market share in a competitive market.
gemma2:2b: The new Apple Mac Mini has received positive reception from fans, experts and PC users alike.
Its low cost, small size, and appeal to iPod owners are seen as key factors for success.
Many analysts predict high demand and a potential market shift for Apple.
Concerns have been raised about the machine's usability with older equipment and its lack of media server functionality.
Despite some reservations, particularly from Brian Gammage, the Mac Mini is expected to contribute to Apple's long-term market share growth in a competitive desktop computer industry.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Apple Mac mini has been welcomed by Apple fans and PC users as an affordable, small, low-cost machine that could appeal to a mass market of iPod owners interested in an easy-to-use second computer.
It is expected to become a big success due to its affordability, large user base ( iPod owners), and ability to be used for browsing the web, email, and basic duties.
The Mac mini could find applications in homes with older peripherals and not as an option for those who expect media servers or digital entertainment services.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Apple's inexpensive, user-friendly Mac mini has received positive reviews and strong sales at its launch event, appealing to Apple fans and iPod owners interested in a low-cost alternative to PCs.
While some experts note concerns about compatibility with older peripherals, the device is expected to capitalize on the iPod's popularity for mass market appeal.
qwen2.5:3b:
Apple Mac mini gets warm welcome

The release of the low-cost, tiny machine has been welcomed by Apple fans and industry experts.
Seen as a promising move for Apple, which currently holds a small share of the desktop market, it's expected to help them appeal to mass consumers.
It will be purchased by iPod owners and others looking for an easy-to-use second home computer.
It's seen as a good idea because it's cheap even for a PC.
Analysts like Nick Ross believe it could win fans due to its ease of use, which is crucial now that people expect things just to work.
Ian Fogg predicts the Mac mini will be very popular with consumers interested in style and small size, aligning well with iPod customers.

However, some critics like Brian Gammage see the Mac mini as merely cheap for an Apple computer compared to many PCs and not appealing enough in categories that few care about when buying a home computer.
He suggests it fits into a long-term trend of Apple's market share decline since ruling the personal computing world.

This tiny, low-cost machine is seen as a good move for Apple which currently has a small share of the desktop computer market.
The Mac mini will go a long way to help Apple appeal to the mass of consumers.
It boasts a hefty price point, making it affordable for those who value high-tech solutions.
Consumers appreciate the sleek design and compact size that make this device a preferred choice.
They also appreciate its affordability, as well as its versatility in handling various types of tasks.

The Mac mini has been seen to have a positive impact on fan behaviour, and thus, industry analysts predict it will be bought by iPod owners and those wanting an easy-to-use and administer second home computer.
The initial press conference concluded with a positive response from many visiting the Apple store that experienced lengthy response times, where businesses couldn't cope without sales.
Following this, a few dissatisfaction points were shared among consumers who misled Apple into thinking it would sell for higher prices.
It has been noted that Apple's work on making things easy to use and aiding sales have also contributed positively to its popularity.
The success of the Mac mini could be attributed to its price point and the fact that it fits perfectly with the trend of PC world.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should be concise and focus on the main ideas:

1.
Apple Mac mini gets warm welcome from fans and industry experts.
The release of the tiny, low-cost machine is seen as a good move for Apple which currently has a small share of the desktop computer market.
The launch of the Mac mini at Macworld Expo was met with enthusiastic responses from attendees who were eager to try out the new product.
The Mac mini is expected to appeal to both iPod owners and those who like Apple technology but do not want to pay high prices for it.
The Mac mini will be available in a range of sizes, including 128GB, 256GB, 320GB, 4096GB, 65536GB and 1TB models.
The machine is expected to sell for £339 in the UK and $499 in the US.
Apple has traditionally done well in the market that the Mac mini is aimed at, but there are also questions over whether it will work with very old peripherals.
Brian Gammage, a senior analyst at Gartner, said that he did not think the Mac mini was particularly innovative or groundbreaking compared to other products on the market.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The Apple Mac mini has garnered praise from Apple fans, industry experts, and PC users, seen as a strategic move for Apple due to its affordability and size compared to previous models.
Jonny Evans noted its appeal to Apple enthusiasts who hadn't been purchasing hardware before, while Mr. Evans highlighted the machine's ability to attract PC users, especially with their friend base.
Ross from PC Pro emphasized its potential as an easy-to-use second computer, covering essential tasks like browsing, email, and is ideal for home use.
The Mac mini was expected to be sold at £339 in the UK and $499 in the US, with extras increasing its price.
However, the machine's perceived simplicity may appeal to older users who might find it odd next to a large monitor.
Gammage from Gartner noted its potential for broader tech enthusiasts due to its versatility beyond media hosting, though Apple had faced market decline before and will recover.
Ross highlighted the release aligning with a trend where each model falls out of favor at intervals after initial gains.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Apple Mac mini has been welcomed by computer experts and analysts due to its small size, low cost, and ease-of-use in appealing to a mass market, as well as the iPod owner community.
Critics such as Jonny Evans, deputy lab manager at PC Pro, have praised the machine's affordability but cautioned about the need for technical improvements.
The Mac mini will be popular among PC users who prefer Apple technology and can be used in homes with second computers that are easy to install and administrate.
For those interested in style, design, and small size, it is a natural next step from iPod users.
However, it may not appeal to those who want a video recordor or media server, and the Mac mini's connectors do not fit for TV screens or enough storage.
Despite this, Apple has seen an increase in demand and is launching the machine at a discounted price of £339 in the UK and $499 in the US.
Critics have expressed concerns over the Mac mini's performance compared to PCs in these categories, but it remains competitive due to the iPod owner community.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Apple has unveiled the new Mac mini as an affordable option for those looking to upgrade their computers.
The compact device offers a range of connectivity options and is designed to be easy-to-use, making it perfect for users who want to save money without sacrificing convenience or performance.
The Mac mini has been praised for its price, with many users expecting it to be sold for around £339 in the UK and $499 in the US.
The machine will go on sale from 22 January, following an announcement made by Apple CEO Tim Cook at the company's annual shareholder meeting.
The Mac mini has been designed with consumers who prioritize style and design in mind, while also catering to those looking for a budget-friendly alternative to larger desktops.
It boasts an impressive 64-bit processor and includes a high-resolution display that is compatible with Apple's eReading technology.
The machine also features up to 1TB of storage, allowing users to easily backup and store their digital media.
Apple has traditionally done well in the market for its Mac mini, as it appeals to a specific audience who prioritize ease of use and functionality over performance.
This release follows on from previous Mac mini announcements, which have seen the machine gain popularity among consumers looking to upgrade their desktop computer without breaking the bank.
However, critics have expressed concerns over how easy other consumers, including those with flat screen TVs and LCD monitors, will find using the Mac mini.
There are also questions over whether it can work with older peripherals such as display, keyboard and mouse.
Gartner analyst Brian Gammage has questioned Apple's ability to innovate in this area, saying it is "very much a computer."

Despite these concerns, the release of the Mac mini is expected to send a significant message to the PC world, as it represents a shift in Apple's marketing strategy and demonstrates its commitment to a more affordable and accessible lineup of products.

With a launch price of around £339 in the UK and $499 in the US, the Mac mini has the potential to appeal to consumers who are looking for an alternative to traditional desktops but still want access to the latest technology.
phi:2.7b: Apple's new Mac mini has received a warm welcome from consumers, industry experts and PC users.
It is seen as an attractive option for those who are not willing or able to pay high prices for Apple technology.
The low-cost machine could potentially appeal to iPod owners and those looking for an easy-to-use second home computer.
However, there are some limitations to the Mac mini, such as its inability to work with very old peripherals and limited storage capacity.
Some experts believe that the release of the Mac mini is just a small step in Apple's overall decline in the personal computing market.
orca-mini:3b: Apple's Mac mini has been welcomed by both fans and industry experts, as well as some analysts who believe it will help Apple appeal to a wider audience.
It is seen as a good move for Apple, which has a small share of the desktop computer market.
The release of the tiny, low-cost machine could help Apple win more sales from other PC makers.
The Mac mini is seen as a good fit for those who prefer Apple technology but are hesitant to spend high prices on a desktop computer.
It can be used by those who have an iPod and want an easy-to-use and administer second home computer.
Some concerns have been raised over the Mac mini's compatibility with old peripherals, and whether it can serve as a media server that also records videos and images.
Despite these concerns, many PC owners are expected to switch to the Mac mini due to its affordability and small size.
hermes3:3b: Apple Mac mini welcomed by fans, industry experts and PC users as affordable option for mass consumers.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Apple's Mac Mini has been warmly received by fans, industry experts and PC users alike.
At a low cost, the small size and large number of iPod users suggest that it could be a big success.
The affordability and absence of viruses are seen as plus points for those who previously couldn't justify paying high prices for Apple's hardware.
It is anticipated that Mac Mini will appeal to those interested in style, design, and ease of use.
Analysts predict that the device will find a role in homes requiring an easily installed and administered second computer for basic duties such as browsing the web and email.
There are concerns, however, regarding how easy others beyond iPod owners will find using the machine, and whether it will be compatible with all old peripherals.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The Mac mini has been well received by Apple fans, industry experts, and PC users, with many seeing it as a smart move to expand Apple's small share of the desktop market.
Analysts believe it will attract iPod owners and those seeking an affordable, easy-to-use second computer.
Its low cost, small size, and Apple's reputation for reliability make it appealing, with some PC users already planning to buy one.
High demand caused Apple’s online store and Macworld Expo site to struggle.
Experts suggest the Mac mini could be popular for basic computing tasks and may benefit from the "halo effect" of iPod sales.
However, concerns exist about compatibility with older peripherals and its limitations as a media server.
Some analysts argue that while the Mac mini is affordable for an Apple product, it remains expensive compared to many PCs and may not significantly alter Apple's market position.
stablelm2:1.6b: Apple's new low-cost Mac mini has received a warm welcome from fans, experts, and users.
It is expected to help Apple appeal to consumers and increase its share in the desktop computer market.
The affordable device may be bought by iPod owners and those seeking an easy-to-use second computer.
Interest in the new products at the recent Macworld expo was high, with websites struggling to cope with demand.
Despite concerns about ease of use for non-iPod users and compatibility with old peripherals, analysts believe it could appeal to a wide range of consumers.
The Mac mini may find a role in homes needing a second computer for basic tasks.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The release of Apple's compact and affordable Mac mini has been met with enthusiasm from fans, experts, and PC users.
Analysts believe it will significantly help Apple capture a larger share of the consumer desktop market by appealing to iPod owners and those seeking an easy-to-use, low-maintenance second computer.
The machine's low cost, small size, and integration with popular iPod technology are key factors in its anticipated success.
Early reactions from Apple enthusiasts and potential buyers indicate strong interest, causing websites for the Apple store to struggle with demand during Macworld Expo.
Experts agree that the Mac mini's ease of use and simplicity make it an attractive option for basic computing tasks like web browsing and email.

Ian Fogg from Jupiter Research sees it as a natural progression for iPod customers, while Nick Ross from PC Pro highlights its potential as a home office computer due to its compact design and expected performance in running essential applications.
However, there are concerns about the Mac mini's compatibility with older peripherals and its limitations as a media server that can record videos and store digital media without additional hardware.

Brian Gammage from Gartner points out that while the Mac mini is competitively priced for an Apple device, it remains expensive compared to many general-purpose PCs in the consumer market, which are seen as interchangeable by most consumers.
Despite these reservations, the Mac mini is expected to spur competition among PC manufacturers to release similar products, reinforcing its potential impact on the broader computing landscape.
